title: Trust in the Lord Instead of in the “Arm of Flesh”
html:
This chapter follows a theme similar to that of the chapter preceding it. However, “the first warning speaks against trusting thewisdom of man, and the second against trusting thepower of man” (Nyman, “Great Are the Words of Isaiah,” p. 118). “Woe to them that go down to Egypt for help,” for there is none there ( Isaiah 31:1). “The Egyptians are men, and not God”; they themselves and those they help “shall fail together” ( v. 3). Only the Lord can save Israel. Isaiah said, “Turn ye unto him from whom the children of Israel have deeply revolted,” and “then shall the Assyrian fall with the sword, not of a mighty man,” but of the Lord ( vv. 6, 8). The “Egyptian” and the “Assyrian” of the latter days may be those in whom a modern people trust rather than in the Lord.

LDS Church Educational System Old Testament Student Manual, 1 Kings–Malachi, Religion 302, Chapter 15, Item 23
